captions.text: Can we ever be certain of anything?

Known as the Father of modern
philosophy, Rene Descartes was

revolutionary in his method of
doubting his way to the Truth.

In order to achieve unshakable
certainty, all falsehoods must be

eliminated. And in order to filter
out faulty knowledge, one must
doubt anything that can be doubted.

In his first two “Meditations,”
Descartes suggests that all

information we receive from our
senses should be called in to
question.

For example, if I put a stick in
water, it will LOOK as if it bends.

But it will FEEL straight.
Therefore, one of my senses must be
deceiving me- or maybe both.

So if our senses are not to be
trusted, how can we be sure of

anything? You may think you’re
slaying Medusa heads in Dracula’s

castle, but how do you know you’re
not dreaming the whole thing? For

as Descartes said “There are never
any sure signs by means of which

being awake can be distinguished
from being asleep”

Even when we are asleep certain
truisms remain. 2+2 still equals 4.

But to Descartes, even that can be
doubted. How?

Imagine, if you will, that an
invisible Evil Genius is filling

our minds with false beliefs in
order to keep us from perceiving

the truth. Silly perhaps. But can
you prove it isn’t true?

However, there is one thing
Descartes discovered that he could

not doubt. If there was, indeed, an
Evil genius hypnotizing me with

false ideas about reality, then I
would have to exist in order for

him to fool me! If I am doubting my
own existence, I must exist in
order to doubt it.

Thus his famous assertion: Cogito
Ergo Sum. Or “I think therefore I
am.” The Evil Genius is defeated!

Or is he? Did Descartes overlook
something? Could his logical

conclusion not also be a product of
the Evil Genius? Truth is, we may
never be certain of anything.

title: Can We Be Certain of Anything? (Descartes) - 8-Bit Philosophy

comments.text:
People should rightly complain about Descartes, because there's a part of 
his formula that is not mentioned here by this video, which bothers me. 
Descartes clearly also states that he could not be entirely deceived 
because God would not allow it. Google "the Cartesian Circle" and you will 
see what is missing from this picture. +Wisecrack why was this not 
included? Descartes was even worse than this video lets on about certainty:

Cartesian Circle (1)Descartes' proof of the reliability of clear and 
distinct perceptions (such as I think therefore I am) takes as a premise 
God's existence as a non-deceiver. (2) Descartes' proofs of God's existence 
presuppose the reliability of clear and distinct perceptions from the 
outset.﻿

comments.author: Mia Malkova

comments.text:
I think it's just that: it works. You set your mind on a goal, gather data, 
test things, seek peer review and things happen in ways that something like 
prayer may not fulfill.

As for absolute truth, by hard philosophical standards, we can never know 
for sure. The hard problem means that I'm not even sure you're conscious or 
anyone else besides me.

But it seems practical to treat you and others like they are conscious, 
since all the empirical data seems that way, and it seems easier to satisfy 
my own goals when I treat people like they're as conscious as I am.

comments.text:
There was a time when crops failed and Inquisitors and witch persecutors 
tried and killed people believing it was caused by blasphemy/heresy. 
Science put an end to that practice by explaining the natural causes behind

prevent them outright.

Here "work" means manipulating states, creating new things. So if prayer 
could prevent rain, that would be really cool and useful. Faith healing 
would be awesome if it actually worked (way more economical and less 
intrusive than modern medicine). Levitation as believed in some traditions 
would be really handy. But so far these things don't seem to work.

The sun will still be there no matter what gods you believe or pray to (or 
lack thereof), crops will still grow, rain will still come.

certain, they usually mean that nothing is certain except that the 
certainty that nothing is certain.

comments.text:
But I believe Descartes DID prove that ATLEAST God wasn't a deceiving 
demon. He did this by understanding perfection. Perfection cannot be a 
concept of something without flaws AND it be a concept of something WITH 
flaws. If the concept of perfection could have flaws, then it is no longer 
perfection. For by the very nature of the concept of perfection, it can be 
no more broken down to be anything else BUT perfection. Descartes could 
imagine a concept of perfection, and it follows then at this concept could 
only come from a Perfect Being. Even an imperfect being could not produce 
the concept of perfection, without there being a Being of Perfection.

It has been argued that, one could imagine a strong man, even by being 
weak. The argument is, you can be imperfect but imagine something greater 
than yourself, without there necessarily being the greater thing in 
existence. I would disagree, because, in order for you to make a comparison 
like that, there needs to be another substance (the greater thing) for you 
to call it "greater". The word "greater" implies that there is something 
greater in and of itself. Now this principle may not apply in all external 
things, but in the absolute sense of the word, it must. 

 Therefore I believe the end part of this video (though i thought 
everything else was awesome) is misleading in my opinion. ﻿

comments.author: Tommy Andreas

comments.text:
+Tommy Andreas I'll rewrite what I meant to say.

"You cannot be certain about anything" is a paradoxical statement. Socrates 
expressed a similar sentiment: "the only thing i know is that i know 
nothing."
Often when this statement is expressed, the expresser implies that the 
statement is the exception (i.e. I know nothing except that I know nothing).
comments.author: Mia Malkova

comments.text:
Hi Mia. If i understand you correctly, are you saying that statment no 1. 
should be formulated differently?

like this: You "should not" be certain about anything, except for this 
statment.
(contrary to: You "cannot be" certain about anything, except for this 
statment)

If so, whats the distinction between "should not", and "cannot"? And what 
difference does it make?

it seems, Mia, still pretty "square circle" to me. Viz. for this reason:

Statment "cannot be certain about anything" implies that i cannot be 
certain about "anything" (including the statement just started).
Statment "should not be certain about anything" implies that should not be 
certain about "anything" (including the statement just started).

still seems self-refuting ...

comments.author: Dan Cosme

comments.text:
Not exactly. We can't be certain of something's veracity, but knowing 
doesn't require absolute veracity. Aristotle knew that the Earth was the 
center of the universe because the Sun traversed the sky. He knew this. We 
know know this to be false, but we can't be verifiably certain we're not 
just brains in a jar being fed sensory data about the sun in order to let 
the Wachowski's write a cool movie with dumb sequels. I can't actually be 
verifiably certain that you exist, and aren't just a comment-generating 
machine or all this is the result of a strangely mundane acid trip, and 
likewise you can't be certain I exist. The only thing either of us can be 
absolutely 100% certain of is our own existence, our own consciousness, an 
"I maker" that experiences events with varying degrees of doubt. 

Also, this is why scientists often hate philosophy, because science hinges 
on certainty that there is an outside world, one separate from an "I maker" 
that can be measured and studied with certainty and precision.

Anyways, man, I'm done with this convo; believe what you will; for you seem

comments.author: Tho Paine

comments.text:

The laws of logic are false.

comments.author: LogicRollsTheDice

comments.text:
+LogicRollsTheDice No, no, no! Have you ever read the Meditations, friend? 
The cogito is *not* derived, but, so to speak, discovered); that is to say, 
its reality, the reality of the cogito, is not based upon deduction, 
contingently, derived from abstract logical propositions or axioms (i.e., 
derived from *presumed* and *presupposed* propositions or axioms).

Meaning, Descartes accepting the fact, in the Meditations, that he, as a 
matter of fact, exists; because he is doubting his existence; is not the 
result of him completing a logical argument. Rather, he is affirming and 
avowing an axiomatic principle which cannot be doubted; for, to doubt it, 
would only affirm its veracity. That is, Descartes can doubt or cast doubt 
upon everything, like the validity and certainty of abstract mathematics 
and scholastic logic, but he cannot, in the same breath, doubt his own 
doubts and doubting of... hence, the cogito is not, in essence, a logical 
argument, but rather, it's an acknowledgement of an indisputable axiom (*now, 
if you're inclined to doubt the certainty of such an "axiom", just let me 
know - wink, wink*).

Yet that's not to say that his argument cannot be articulated into logical 
form; but that the crux of the argument, his argument, is not, in essence, 
a creation of logical propositions.
comments.author: Tho Paine

comments.text:
+Tho Paine It's actually *backwards*. The cogito depends on the laws of 
logic. It's a tautology. It is deduced via modus ponens. Cogito ergo sum is 
a definitional relationship.
comments.author: LogicRollsTheDice

comments.text:
+LogicRollsTheDice "Secondly, the incompleteness theorem becomes 
meaningless if it is not provable either. As you cannot assert that 
incompleteness is necessarily the case (which is what you want to do)."

You're missing the point (and seem to have lost any idea, why, and for what 
reason, we started this long back and forth; go back and re-read this convo 
from the beginning, friend): the method is dubitable, BUT THE ONE UTILIZING 
IT IS NOT! In other words, the COGITO is the knowledge which can indubitbly 
stand (while the methods the cogito may go on to utilize, are, per se, 
ultimately mistaken).

system and to say there is a situation wherein they do not apply, is to say 
that they either apply or they don't but not both, and if you say both, 
then it's either both or not both, and both is the same thing as not 
applying as distinct from do apply."

Lol, you do know that on a quantum level the law of non-contradiction isn't 
applicable to reality, right? While it (the law) may apply to how we, as 
cognizing *subjects*, filter and understand reality (*relatively*), 
Meaning, things can be in two places at once and, certain a particle can be 
itself whilst not be itself at the same exact time (i.e., A≠A), that is to 
say, a particle can both be a wave *and* a particle at the same time. Your 
laws of logic are arbitrary, and not necessary. You haven't proven 
otherwise... but presumed much...
comments.author: Tho Paine

comments.text:
+LogicRollsTheDice Are you still missing the idea that I am saying that the 
provability of this being as so, IS NOT *possible* outside of the bounds of 
OUR own self-enclosed logic; meaning, *outside* of a relation to OUR system 
for appraisal, i.e., objectively, such "facts" are not 
verifiable/demonstratable (but only PRESUMED by the grounding condition for 
all possible knoweldge, i.e., the cogito [for the millionth time]). There's 
a reason that, even Godel himself conceded that the incompleteness theorem 
itself, ironically enough, cannot with be proven with apodictic certainty 
(but only presumed).

And again, you skip over, and through, everything without actually 
explaining a single thing. So, what does the incompleteness thereom entail, 
Logic?
comments.author: Tho Paine

comments.text:
+Tho Paine The laws of thought aren't *just* axioms. If they aren't true, 
then they aren't true, that's identity.

The laws of thought are required to arrive at the incompleteness theorem, 
an actual *theorem*.

"Exactly, its negation is not true WITHIN the (self-referential) system, 
i.e., within a relation to the arbitrary system!"

And yet they transcend the system, because - and don't dare say I haven't 
addressed this - _negation is meaningful inside the system and to say there 
is a situation wherein they do not apply, is to say that they *either apply 
or they don't but not both*, and if you say both, then it's either both or 
not both, and both is the same thing as not applying as distinct from do 
apply.

They transcend your model.
comments.author: LogicRollsTheDice

comments.text:
+LogicRollsTheDice Why are you so hardheaded? That is exactly what the 
incompleteness theorem ultimately infers (you know, throughout this entire 
back and forth of ours, you've simply just talked about what it is you 
think, *without* actually explaining one single thing); and if not, please 
enlighten me as to what the theorem entails?

"And as far as certainty is concerned, it's about internal consistency, and 
since A=A is internally consistent and can demonstrate it's negation not 
being true."

Exactly, its negation is not true WITHIN the (self-referential) system, 
i.e., within a relation to the arbitrary system! And yet, such a supposed 
"fact" CANNOT be demonstrated with apodictic certainty *outside* of 
relativity, i.e., objectively; but only *presumed* and *presupposed* by a 
mind (thus spoke the incompleteness theorem).
comments.author: Tho Paine

comments.author: Adam Weiss

comments.text:
What if we look within ourselves? We try to look for and wonder about 
reality outside of ourselves, through inch-thick goggles of our own 
perception. We will only ever be able to see outside of ourselves, what is 
real to US.  We can think, we can feel.. through this, we know we're real. 
But are we really? Well, we are in our collective perception and 
consciousness. That should be real enough. We are alive because of it. We 
are one of the species in our own plane of reality. So why not bask and 
grow in and via that reality, that certain and true reality, instead of 
looking for reality elsewhere, that we cannot find via our limiting senses? 
Reality lies inside of US. Meaning lies inside of US. If we make use of 
what we are truly capable of, we won't have to look for truth in the world 
through merely the mechanics of our bodies and brains. But we CAN go very 
far with them, with an especially open mind. Further than most of us know. 
Quantum mechanics took a great step in the right direction but it's not 
very widely accepted. Here come the conspiracies theorists for reasons like 
this. ﻿

Bill: Ted, you and I have witnessed many things, but nothing as bodacious

Ted: What if we were lying?
Bill: Why would we lie to ourselves?

comments.author: douglas “Ansury” wahid

comments.text:
It's an important thought experiment that the West had to go through, but 
ultimately a dead end. There's no path from "cogito ergo sum" to anything 
else, so either you give up and curl up into a little ball and lie there, 
or you get on with your life and accept skeptical uncertainty as an 
unfortunate necessity. How to do *that* would have been a worthwhile topic 
for Descartes to discuss.﻿
comments.author: HebaruSan

comments.text: My head just exploded.﻿
comments.author: joert4455

comments.text:
We may never be certain of anything...
I'm okay with that.

When I first saw this, I thought of The Matrix.
Why did those people want to stop the machines?
Because they hated how their fellow humans were being treated.

Why did they give a crap?
Everyone was "asleep". Who cares if they weren't really living?
Their bodies were safe, and were disposed of when no longer needed.
Isn't that what we do in real life?
Hold onto what we have, until we no longer "need" it?

I don't care if my whole life is just a dream.
I'm still not happy, there are still people I hate, there are still things 
to be discovered, things to do, things to be seen, felt, heard, eaten.

How different would the world be, if I wasn't dreaming?
What would change?
Would it be better, worse, or the same?

Kick back, relax, and drink a beer or two. Spread some love, or fuck 
everybody!
This is the life we've got, and whether it's the only one or not, it'll 
have to do for now.

Peace, love, and chicken, bitches!﻿

existence only has one quality-> to exist. Everything else is secondary.

was my thoughts, but now I know I am not.
I am the observer, nothing more, nothing less.
Without memory, there is only one moment in existence, and that is Now.
Memory creates the illusion of time. the space between two thoughts.
Green is only green because someone told you so.
 ﻿

comments.text:
Logic is based on assumption, especially mathematics. If I just invented 
mathematics, I can say to you, 2+2 is 17, and this will be true, by 
definition, from a mathematical standpoint. 2 and 17 are both arbitrary 
terms, and therefore can be used to mean anything I want, as long as it's 
consistant﻿
comments.author: andrew sauer

comments.text:
Now wait a minute. Descartes seemed pretty adamant about cognito ergo sum 
being incorrigible truth.

Say you reached the same conclusion that Descartes did. You think therefore 
you are. Now someone wants to say you imagined the whole thing. But the 
point is you believe you are something; in this case, you are the person 
who dreamed the ultimate cognito ergo sum revelation, and as long as you 
believe you are something,  then you exist. No one can trick you into 
believing you aren't something. You know you are something. It's the what's 
why's and how's that can be tricky.﻿

The funny thing is that our brains do actually filter most of our 
information and omit massive parts of what we see.  For more on that, look 
at the study of the Invisible Gorilla.  The most dangerous enemy (and 
friend) of our minds is our rather terrible brain structure.  It designed 
to keep us alive and sane, not to make us more intelligent and rational.﻿

comments.author: Frederick Charles

comments.text:
"...silly perhaps, but can you prove it's not true?"

I take it that Descartes had never heard of the negative proof fallacy. 
 Also, "I think therefor I am" is a tautology.  A compelling one, I'll give 
you that.  Finally, we cannot always trust our senses, that's why we make 
many, many observations, compile them together, then use statistics to rule 
out the possibility that our observed correlations/predicted outcomes (or 
lack thereof) are not the result of error or random chance.

I've commented on several of these videos in a row now and should point out 
that several of my friends are political theorists.  For those who don't 
know, political theorists do normative research on questions of political 
philosophy.  They largely ignore the behavioral wing of that branch of 
social science and ignore the scientific method.  So I've heard all this 
nonsense before.

Also, why all the focus on Western philosophers?  I haven't seen one video 
yet on Buddhist, Taoist, Confucianist, Hindu, &c. philosophy yet.﻿

This is interesting when applied to scientific philosophy, as in order to 
do science we must start with a few basic assumptions: 1. that the universe 
exists, 2. that we can learn something about the world.  These assumptions 
are a basic necessity that help produce practical rests within the universe 
even if it is an illusion.  Which is not to say that Descartes perspective 
is not interesting and fun to contemplate.  Perhaps it is not an evil 
actor, but some kid playing Sims 3033.﻿
